The sage-kings Yao and Shun were as benevolent as Heaven itself, yet they did not pardon the Four Criminals. The Duke of Zhou cherished his brothers, yet he did not spare the Two Uncles. When Confucius executed Shaozheng Mao and Emperor Wu of Han put his nephew to death, their tears fell as they lamented the necessity of the law—such was their inescapable duty.

Thus, to punish one is to warn ten thousand; to sacrifice the few is to preserve the many. Compared to combing one’s hair, the benefit reaches the multitude; likened to excising a carbuncle, the preservation is of the greater whole. Acupuncture and moxibustion are cruelly painful yet cannot be halted, for they cure disease; punishments are grim and harsh yet cannot be abolished, for they remedy corruption.

Though the six armies stand dense as a forest, not all are truly brave. To charge through blades and plunge into fire is what human nature dreads. Yet if one urges with gentle countenance, few will risk their lives; if one enforces with decisive execution, none will fail to fight fiercely. Thus, those who labor with smiles do not match the speed of those roused by shouts; those who govern with inducements do not equal the order imposed by punishments.

Therefore, even the safe and contented in deep valleys must uphold strict laws, just as Wei Zi hastened to punish those who discarded ashes, enforcing severe penalties. To use what men fear to restrain what they trifle with—this is the way to ensure sternness without transgression, the art of preserving the people.

The skill of a master physician lies in preventing illness before it arises; the insight of one who grasps order and chaos lies in averting future calamities. Yet if light punishments are used to forbid grave crimes, or lenient laws to protect great benefits, and these are proclaimed with ever greater clarity, offenders only multiply—like digging a pit to block the road, a course no humane ruler would embrace.

The wise governor must first correct himself to lead others, discipline his kin to order the distant, never bend the law to follow whim, and punish all crimes without pardon. Like Shi Shi of old, who cut off affection to execute his kin, or Duke Wen of Jin, who stifled sentiment to behead Jie Zitui.

Thus, benevolence is but the cosmetics of governance; punishments are the reins and bridle of the age. Cosmetics are not the most urgent need of the body, yet reins and bridle cannot be absent even for a moment. If solemn reverence slackens but slightly, indolence and disrespect soon follow; if awe and severity falter for an instant, the multitude of evils stirs in the heart.

When anger is right but not expressed, treacherous ministers become tigers; when killing is due but not carried out, great bandits arise. Water, long neglected, breaches the river; mountains rise from a span’s height. A towering tree of a thousand feet begins with a hair’s breadth; the fire from drilling tinder can be quenched with a ladle of water; the egg of a swan, unhatched, can be crushed in the palm. But when it rides the whirlwind and scorches the great plain, or spreads its six wings to soar above the morning clouds, then even the wise and brave cannot restrain it.

Therefore, the enlightened ruler resolves difficulties while they are easy, eradicates evil while it is small, does not boast of virtue to foster disorder, nor hesitates like one grasping an axe handle. Thus, punishments are the sacred instruments of the state, to be wielded by the ruler alone, never entrusted to others—like a great sword that cannot be grasped by the blade, or a giant fish that cannot be removed from the deep.

Here lies the origin of rise and decline, the source of safety and peril. Tian Chang’s usurpation of Qi, the Six Ministers’ partition of Jin, Zhao Gao’s assassination of the Qin emperor, Wang Mang’s usurpation of Han—each followed the path from frost to ice, a gradual accumulation. Some sighed forever by the sea, others clutched their hearts at Wangyi Palace; their disasters extended to their ancestral temples, serving as warnings to later ages. All stemmed from admiring empty reputations of antiquity while forgetting the real calamities at hand.

Someone may say: “The rise of penal laws belongs to the declining age.”

The Way of establishing humanity lies solely in benevolence and righteousness. When I am serene, the people naturally rectify themselves; when I am without desire, the people naturally return to simplicity. The caution against overcooking delicate fish is to avoid excess. Govern with leniency and love, and the masses will gather; employ joy in command, and subordinates will submit. Thus Mencius deemed embodying benevolence as peace, while Yang Xiong called Shen Buhai and Han Fei butchers. Excessive reins and tight bridles are not the driving of Zaofu; harsh punishments and severe penalties are not the Way of the Three Dynasties and Five Emperors. Therefore, in the time of Youyu, the ruler did not point or issue verbose commands—merely sitting in reverent dignity facing south, and governance flourished in harmony. Fu Sheng led by example, strumming the zither and chanting poetry without leaving his hall, yet fishermen and hunters observed propriety by night. If one can bestow generous favors and lighten taxes, relieve the destitute and promote the overlooked, appoint the worthy and employ the capable, encourage agriculture and reduce expenditures, attract the estranged with ritual and embrace the distant with virtue, cultivate them through education and govern them through schools—then those who inspire goodness from above will be like grass bending before a sudden wind, and those who wash their hearts and reform their countenances will be like clear waves cleansing light dust. The court will be filled with lords who yield in virtue, the countryside will know no transgressions against propriety. Prisons may lie empty, whips may forever be set aside—why must rewards and punishments alone govern the state?”

The Master of Embracing Simplicity replied: “The *Book of Changes* speaks of ‘clarifying punishments and rectifying laws,’ while the *Book of Documents* urges ‘compassion in adjudicating cases.’ Conferring ranks at court and executing criminals in the marketplace have been practiced since antiquity—how can this be confined to a declining age? Excessive benevolence prevents laws from being established; insufficient awe allows inferiors to encroach upon superiors. If laws are not established, all affairs become chaotic; if inferiors encroach upon superiors, rebellion becomes manifest. The purest virtue was already diluted by the Three Dynasties, and the great simplicity further scattered under Qin and Han. The Dao has declined since ancient times, customs have grown shallow in the present age—yet one seeks to govern deceit with knotted cords, transform cunning with silence, abandon reins and whip to ride a galloping horse on treacherous paths, discard rudder and oar to navigate a drifting boat through waves, chase thieves in circles, extinguish fires with bows and courtesies, execute Chao Cuo to repel the Seven States, or brandish weapons to pacify the Red Eyebrows—such measures are clearly unfeasible!

For the Three Sovereigns walked while the Five Emperors galloped; from the age of hegemons and kings onward, the pace has only quickened. When governance decays, officials deceive and the people scheme, bandits and thieves operate openly. Shaving heads and applying shackles fail to deter the shameless; exterminating clans cannot curb ambition. Eyes are multiplied to broaden vision, ears are piled to extend hearing, candles are raised to resolve backlogged affairs, hearts are scorched to stem the source of treachery—yet the marketplace and court still echo with sighs, the frontiers still harbor unheard injustices. Those who wield power arbitrarily may act beneath a single glance; those who harm the state and endanger the realm may plot within the palace walls. To govern a shallow and degenerate age with the Way of Taihao, or quell a boiling cauldron’s chaos with a single unchanging song, is to fail to recognize the need for adaptation with the times and the necessity of adjusting measures to circumstances. It is like carving a mark on a boat to retrieve a lost sword, shooting an arrow three days’ flight to strike a target five paces away, discarding rhinoceros-hide armor to wade into unfathomable depths, or casting off a fur coat in sweltering heat—such confusion is unparalleled!

One should first issue commands and only then punish, secure the truth without delighting in it, so that the Lord of Bo feels no resentment over his lost fief, and the men of Yu and Rui feel shame and abandon litigation. But if the violent conceal their nature, grasping the executioner’s rope without fear; if one is lured by tolerance into letting corruption spread unchecked—relying on grand words to conceal deep illness while forgetting the urgency of one’s fatal condition—how is this different from one parched with thirst pointing to a distant sea a myriad miles away, or drowning in a deluge while building a boat in the forest of Changzhou? How can one escape the fate of Kuafu or evade the disaster of the Flood?

The world scorns the practical methods of Shen Buhai and Han Fei while praising the fanciful discourses of Laozi and Zhuangzi. Yet in governance, they cannot do without punishments—pardoning killers, absolving assailants—like offering half a tile or a shard of pottery to a starving man at dawn, utterly useless. The words of Daoists are lofty indeed, but their application leads to ruin. They are as impractical as using a *ganjiang* sword to sew thread, an elephant to catch mice, a golden boat to brave towering waves, or a jade horse to gallop a thousand miles. To follow their teachings would require burning shackles and razing prisons, abolishing officials and erasing penal codes, melting down weapons and leveling city walls, dispersing treasuries and destroying tally tokens, dismantling barriers and toll stations, breaking scales and measures. One would blind Li Zhu’s eyes and deafen Zi Ye’s ears, drifting untethered, returning to the governance of Heaven—without instruction or management, forgetting all in rivers and lakes. The court would be as silent as if empty, the people would never interact even unto death. Such theories may be discussed, but they cannot be practiced.

Vulgar scholars merely hear that the Zhou rose through benevolence and the Qin fell through severity, yet fail to realize that the Zhou’s success was not purely benevolent, nor the Qin’s downfall solely due to harshness. In ancient times, the Zhou employed corporal punishments—amputating feet and slicing noses. At the covenant of Mengjin, latecomers were beheaded; rewards and punishments were enforced with utmost rigor, oaths included the slaughter of families. Examining their deeds, they were not entirely benevolent. By the late Zhou, laws were disregarded and texts manipulated, rulers grew tyrannical, edicts failed to reach beyond the cosmos, rites and music, punitive expeditions—all were no longer decided by the throne. Officials vied for power, turning into a coiling serpent. Cutting off the root and blocking the source, they destroyed crowns and rent robes. Some were drowned in the Han River, others exiled to Zhizhi. The collapse of the Zhou stemmed from insufficient severity. When the Qin first rose, officials were appointed based on talent. Men like Shang Yang and You Yu implemented laws within; generals like Bai Qi and Wang Jian conquered without.”

Uniting the weak and attacking the benighted, seizing might to establish hegemony, they devoured neighboring states and crushed rival lords, expanding territory and repelling the Rong. With the dragon’s transformation and the dragon’s gaze, they relied on clear rewards and certain punishments to lay the foundation of imperial enterprise.

Yet as the dynasty declined into its final years, rulers grew arrogant in triumph, indulging in boundless extravagance. They compounded this with tyranny: building walls a myriad *li* long, constructing over a thousand detached palaces, and amassing bells, drums, and female musicians without restraint. The labor at Mount Li, the levy of two-thirds taxation, the conscription of the poor, the brutality of burying scholars alive, the northern campaign against the Xianyun, the southern conquest of the Baiyue—armies of a million were mobilized for decades on end. The realm mourned with the sorrow of separation, every household sighed with resentment and neglect. White bones piled into mountains, empty sacrifices spread across the wilds. When Xu Fu departed, he left behind a legacy of countless foes; when Zhao Gao entered, he gathered a pack of jackals and wolves. The world yearned to rebel, and nine out of ten homes stood empty. Yet its downfall was not due to severity—this was how Qin had gained power, not how it lost it.

“For punishment arises from the blade: the skilled wield it to perfect themselves, while the clumsy wound themselves with it. In governing the state by the Dao, when punishment is applied as an aid, it can suppress deceit and falsehood, turning the wicked from their ways. But if the net’s ropes are severed and its mesh disordered, offending Heaven and misapplying punishment without reason, ruin will come swiftly. It is like water and fire, which sustain life yet also take it—it depends on whether one can use them or not.

“If tumors and growths are left untreated and one does not practice the arts of Bian Que, how can one hope for the longevity of Lao Peng? If treacherous factions multiply yet no strict system is enforced to punish transgressions, how can one expect enduring prosperity? One must select men like Zhang Tang to administer the law and govern the age, and choose officials like Zhao Yu and Chen Chong to investigate and impeach. The enlightened ruler remains vigilant above, while loyal ministers devote themselves below. At the sight of wrongdoing, they strike like hawks and falcons seizing sparrows; upon spying the first signs of disorder, they clear it like pheasants and pheasants weeding the fields. Rewards are bestowed without error, and executions are meted out only to the guilty—then the path to Great Peace need not be sought elsewhere. If decrees are obeyed without violation, one may nearly abolish punishment and achieve order, though I dare not assert this with certainty.”

Some asked, “If punishments truly aid instruction and foster goodness, why do they sometimes deviate from the proper standard? And as for the corporal punishments of old, could they be revived?”

The *Baopuzi* replied, “Why not? In ancient times, the Zhou employed corporal punishments and endured for seven hundred years. The Han abolished them, yet its reign was shorter. Later, they were replaced with flogging and caning, which resulted in many deaths. Outwardly, this appeared as leniency, but in truth, it was a means of killing. When crimes did not warrant death, the only alternatives were exile, flogging, or caning. If an amnesty was granted, the offender suffered no lasting harm—shaving the hair of one who had just begun to regrow it, or striking wounds that had only just healed, hardly sufficed to punish crimes deserving of death. Now, with corporal punishments abolished, there is no intermediate penalty between death and lesser punishments. Thus, crimes deserving of death short of execution are left unaddressed by anything but exile, flogging, or caning, creating an imbalance in severity. Moreover, while capital offenses are rare, those deserving of death but not execution are common. If corporal punishments are not used, such crimes often go unpunished.

“If, however, crimes other than treason, rebellion against ruler or kin, military offenses in the face of the enemy, or murder by one’s own hand were punished by corporal penalties instead of death, this would suffice to deter the wicked. The punished could still perform labor, contribute to society, and preserve their lives, while their lifelong disfigurement would strike fear into the hearts of all who saw them, deterring future offenses more effectively than execution. Killing is no light matter, yet after three days, the condemned are buried and forgotten—few witness it, and fewer remember. But corporal punishment serves as a lasting warning.

“In the Wei dynasty, this matter was frequently debated. Eminent scholars and learned men well-versed in governance all agreed that corporal punishments should be restored, though dissenters opposed them—yet their objections were unconvincing. Even Emperor Wu of Wei concurred. The only reason it was not implemented was that the frontiers were not yet pacified, and distant peoples, upon hearing that China severed limbs and sliced off ears and noses, would have taken it as proof of cruelty. Thus, it was temporarily suspended until the realm was unified. The erudite Yang Xiong also believed corporal punishments should be revived, but as they had been abolished for so long, those who sat in judgment did not consider it urgent.”

Bao Puzi states: The towering heights of Mount Hua and Mount Heng reach the heavens precisely because their foundations run deep. The resplendent achievements of Yao and Shun were made possible only through the excellence of their ministers. Though one may possess the skill of Sun Yang, without the swift hooves of a *qiji*, one cannot traverse a thousand *li*. Though one may have the talent to delve into antiquity, without capable aides to put it into effect, one cannot consolidate the manifold tasks of governance.

Though a ruler’s wisdom may rival the sun and moon, and his divine insight discern even the faintest signs, the myriad affairs of state cannot be managed alone, nor can every minute detail be personally overseen. He must rely on eyes to survey distant matters and ears to extend his hearing, truly requiring officials to uphold and assist the realm. Thus, no sagely ruler fails to seek worthies from the depths of his heart, making the recruitment of talent his foremost duty. He bestows jade and silk upon recluses in their rustic retreats, dispatches carriages to the wilds and marshes, toiling in the search for men while reaping ease in their employment. From the highest ministers beneath the scholar-tree to the lowliest gatekeepers, all charged with governing the Dao and ordering the state are entrusted with their duties.

Through reverent self-cultivation and non-action, order prevails and punishments fall into disuse; transformation spreads without limit, and the myriad states enjoy peace.

chunks.translated_text:
Establishing offices and dividing duties is like constructing a hall—if a single component is unfit, it becomes the cause of collapse. Now, those recommended for office are measured by the four standards, and from the three offices and nine ranks they emerge. One must select the most outstanding and exceptional talents. Yet in the late years of the Han, during the reigns of Emperors Huan and Ling, power departed from the imperial house and rested with treacherous ministers. The net of governance leaked, defenses crumbled, moral winds declined, and instruction faltered. They suppressed those of pure virtue and promoted flatterers, demoted those who trod the Way and advanced the wealthy. Striving for advantage became the custom, and shameless pursuit of gain went unchecked. Some offered bribes of self-promotion, others sold letters of recommendation from influential men. Some, by virtue of their fathers’ or elder brothers’ prominence, received appointments merely by standing before the gate; others, through bowing and scraping, were repeatedly recruited after long practice.

When the scales of assessment are unbalanced, weights and measures become confused; when measuring vessels are untrue, quantities are muddled; when the marking line is not laid out, straight and crooked cannot be distinguished. If standards are skewed, impurities proliferate. Ruling the people in this manner leads to cruelty and rapacity—officials extort and amass wealth to recoup the cost of buying their posts. Placed in the court, they bring chaos like tangled silk. They appoint the incompetent and mediocre as their clique, yet expect the wind to bend the grass and all affairs to prosper. How is this different from hanging shards of tile and demanding luminous pearls, or plucking an untuned string and seeking pure sound?

How can one not purify the turbid and elevate the sunken, sift the worthy from the unworthy, enforce rigorous examination procedures, and heighten defenses against the greedy? The roots of ruin and suffering—how can they not be feared?

In ancient times, when the feudal lords presented scholars, those who were suitable were deemed meritorious, and the meritorious had their ranks advanced and titles elevated; those who were unsuitable were deemed at fault, and the faulty had their positions demoted and lands reduced. Yet even then, they could not prevent the *Shi* poets from composing satires like *"The Great Cart"* and *"Eating Without Labor,"* or the worthy from the mountains and forests from lamenting *"Felling Sandalwood"* and *"Trapping Hares."* How much worse, then, is the crime of recommending the unworthy and the calamity of appointing those unfit for their posts?

Once the scales of assessment lose their standard, how can the many and the few be adjusted? The solitary and outstanding conceal their talents, awaiting a fair price; the petty and frivolous curry favor through connections to hasten their advancement. Only by awaiting their true worth do the former sink into poverty and distress; only by rushing do the latter leap forward through deceit.

When kites and owls flock together, phoenixes retreat into seclusion; when jackals and wolves block the path, qilin flee afar. Promote the good and instruct the people, and the unvirtuous will distance themselves; let the treacherous and false gain honor, and the heroic and outstanding will vanish. Those of lofty integrity disdain association with the base, and the pure of conduct are ashamed to join the ranks of the gluttonous.

When appointments are uniformly mistaken, the worthy withdraw in silence; when the worthy withdraw in silence, the wicked draw near to one another; when the wicked draw near, the path of petty men lengthens; when the path of petty men lengthens, *Taowu* monsters stand shoulder to shoulder. This is why odes of praise are not composed and why cries of resentment rise in a clamor.

Those of towering talent, relying on abilities surpassing their own, bend or stand, speak or remain silent, submitting to Heaven and entrusting their fate to nature. In success or failure, gain or loss, they yield to spontaneity. How, then, can they not fall behind the faction-ridden and stand beneath the powerful? The reclusive and exceptional, who move only in accord with ritual, stand firm as mountains and deep as abysses—few recognize them. The ambitious and scheming slander and obscure them. Thus, even a ruler who seeks the worthy may never learn where extraordinary talent resides, and those who embrace the Way may wish to offer their service but find no path.

Though possessing the talents of Hou Ji and Xie, and the capacity to surpass the age, they sink into obscurity until death, never gaining rank or position. Meanwhile, those with factions and influence gather like scales in abundance. With men scarce and offices vacant, and those appointed deemed excellent, how can one not gather and employ them?

In the reigns of Emperors Ling and Xian, eunuchs held power, and a cabal of villains wielded authority, endangering the loyal and good. The central court failed in its selection of officials above, while the provinces and commanderies treated recommendations lightly below. When selection fails above, governors and prefects are not the right men; when recommendations are treated lightly below, the worthy and filial are not chosen.

Thus, the people of the time said: *"Recommend a Filial and Incorrupt, and he does not know his books; examine a Filial and Upright, and his father lives apart. The poor and pure are muddied like sludge, while the high-ranking and capable are timid as chickens."* They also said: *"In ancient times, one studied the classics diligently to advance; in this age, one seeks office to avoid labor."* Such was the depth of their indignation.

At that time, offices were hung out for sale like goods in a shop; those competing for passage bought them like market-goers. The upright, though without connections, advanced directly; the empty-handed, gazing at the road, were swept into the ranks. Those who paid more gained higher office; those who paid less received lower posts. Thus, the Eastern Gardens amassed money from selling offices, and Cui Lie was mocked for the stench of copper.

The superior set the example, and the inferior followed with greater zeal. Flatterers and favorites monopolized favor, while discussions of local worthies, the Impartial and Just, and the Ministry of Personnel all became brokers, each demanding their price. How could the pure and poor have any hope? Such was the state of affairs.

Moreover, the crooked and the upright are as incompatible as ice and charcoal; those who detest integrity despise those who refuse to join their factions. Those who wield power with perverse measures fear others’ criticism of themselves; those who attain success without following the Dao dread that their reputation may not be fair. Thus, they conspire to fabricate false accusations, slandering the pure and virtuous, heaping baseless flaws upon them, so that none dare to rescue or promote them. As a result, the virtuous like Zeng and Min endured the slander of Shang Chen, while the wise like Confucius and Mozi bore the stain of Robber Zhi. Those who uphold integrity and abide in constancy are mired in the mud and mire, while the cunning and deceitful soar like rainbows in the sky.

Yet the shallow-minded, unable to distinguish between the crooked and the upright, call those who guard the Dao "sunken in obscurity" and praise those who tread crooked paths as "adept at adaptation." When customs sway with the wind and drift with the current, how can men ever return to virtue and discipline, or devote themselves to learning? Thus, all abandon the toil of self-restraint and hasten toward the swift gains of bribery. This is indeed the reason for the Han’s downfall—a lesson future generations must deeply heed.

Someone asked: "Your critique of the Han’s late imperial examinations is indeed accurate in diagnosing its ills. If we now wish to guard against past mistakes, avoid the path of a collapsing cart, change the tune of the present age, and prevent the erosion of laws, so that the rustic tunes of Pu Shang give way to the proper music of *An Le*, and that minor ailments do not fester into chronic afflictions—is there a method for this? Some scholars possess noble bearing and abundant grace, yet harbor emptiness within, lacking substance in their aspirations. If we judge by appearance alone, we may not necessarily select the worthy; if we proceed slowly with preliminary trials, we cannot act in haste. What, then, is to be done?"

The *Baopuzi* replied: "To know men is wisdom—even the greatest sages find it difficult. If we now require all governors and prefects to discern true talent before employment and ensure the integrity of their conduct from beginning to end, this is no easy task. Yet if they set aside personal bias, exhaust their wisdom, remain unmoved by profit or desire, and refuse to yield to favoritism or pressure, then for those they wish to recommend, they must carefully observe and thoroughly investigate, examining their reputation and scrutinizing their conduct, comparing accounts to guard against deception. Let their kinsfolk praise their filial piety and brotherly love, and let their villages and towns attest to their trustworthiness and righteousness. If they have held minor office, let their loyalty, purity, and administrative skill be proven—then even a scrap of brocade reveals their craftsmanship, and a mouse caught in a trap demonstrates their courage.

Furthermore, all candidates for *xiucai* and *xiaolian* should, as before, be tested on the classics and policy questions to prevent deceit in their responses. Those who fail must be rejected outright, and the officials responsible should be punished with demotion and prohibition from office. If the candidates they recommend fail, the prefects and governors should be dismissed; if they pass in small numbers, the officials should be demoted. Those who pass in greater numbers may not be promoted beyond their previous rank. If one accepts bribes and recommends the unworthy, and this is discovered and verified, they shall be stripped of office and barred for life, with no pardon by imperial decree. The recommended and the recommender shall share the same punishment. If this law is enforced for one or two years, the number of *xiucai* and *xiaolian* candidates will surely decrease, and this will suffice to reveal how long the empire’s selection process has been imprecise. After this, those who cultivate virtue and diligently study will surely increase.

Moreover, for all officials in office: if they commit public offenses, let the law take its course. If they are guilty of corruption or graft but not deserving of death, upon completion of their sentence or pardon, they should be barred from office for life—twenty years for lesser offenses. Thus, even the most corrupt officials will surely transform into Boyi and Shuqi. But if those who take bribes while in office amass wealth like mountains, and upon exposure merely plead for leniency, or if they are dismissed only to be reappointed within days, then even Zeng and Shi will turn into Robber Zhi. In such a case, even if all recommended scholars are qualified, they will have no recourse against unworthy superiors."

Some may ask: "One who speaks well may not necessarily act well. Even if candidates pass the examination and policy response, how can we be certain they possess administrative talent?"

The Master Embracing Simplicity replies: "In ancient times, archery was used to select men—how much more should we value mastery of the classics? If we abandon this method, I have yet to see a better alternative. Lush grasses do not grow in barren soil; giant fish do not spawn in shallow streams. Profound words do not fall from the mouths of mediocre men, nor do lofty writings flow from the brushes of the dull-witted.

Thus, perusing the *Hong Fan*, one recognizes that Jizi possessed the capacity to order the world. Reading the *Nine Strategies*, one sees that Fan Li harbored the art of governing a state. Examining the writings of Guan Zhong, one discerns his talent for restoring order from chaos. Studying the texts of Shen Buhai, one perceives his mastery of the Dao of hegemony and kingship.

Today, if candidates for filial piety and incorruptibility must pass the classics without error, and those recommended for exceptional talent must respond to policy questions without misinterpretation, then they cannot remain obscure or concealed. Even the finest generals, selected for their courage and martial prowess, are further tested through policy responses—how much more should this apply to scholars?

Granted, this method may not guarantee the selection of all worthy and capable individuals, but it is surely superior to no testing at all. At present, let this single measure be applied to all those eligible for recommendation and examination: none will dare neglect their studies. This alone will greatly benefit the cultivation of customs and education.

If the realm fears the consequences of reckless recommendations, if all men abandon their pursuit of undeserved fortune, turn away from petty competition, and return to the foundation of learning, then the Dao of the Ru will flourish, private bribery will gradually cease, extraordinary talents will be employed, and official posts will no longer lie vacant."

Another objects: "Sir, you advocate strict examination laws, yet the punishment of lifelong disbarment is harsh and severe, striking fear into many. Tight reins and frequent spurring are practices even Bo Le would avoid; stringent laws and rigid prohibitions are a disgrace to virtuous governance."

The Master Embracing Simplicity replies: "Medicines that strengthen bones and nourish flesh excel at sustaining the body and prolonging life, but they cannot rescue one drowning in imminent peril. Policies of leniency and tolerance may suit the governance of the honest and simple, but they cannot remedy the decline and decay of an age.

When beset by tigers and wolves, if one does not brandish a spear or unsheathe a sword but instead strums the zither and recites poetry, I have yet to see how such a person can preserve their life. When flames engulf a house, if one does not rush to pour water but instead bows and defers in ceremony, I have yet to see how the fire will extinguish itself.

To discuss this with those who knowingly sell their schemes is like debating the capture of thieves with Robber Zhi."

chunks.original_text: 抱朴子曰：“今普天一统，九垓同风，王制政令，诚宜齐一。 夫衡量小器，犹不可使往往有异，况人士之格，而可叁差而无检乎江表虽远，密迩海隅，然染道化，率礼教，亦既千余载矣。 往虽暂隔，不盈百年，而儒学之事，亦不偏废也。 惟以其土宇褊於中州，故人士之数，不得钧其多少耳。 及其德行才学之高者，子游仲任之徒，亦未谢上国也。 昔吴土初附，其贡士见偃以不试。 今太平已近四十年矣，犹复不试，所以使东南儒业衰於在昔也。 此乃见同於左衽之类，非所以别之也。 且夫君子犹爱人以礼，况为其恺悌之父母邪！ 法有招患，令有损化，其此之谓也。 今贡士无复试者，则必皆修饰驰逐，以竞虚名，谁肯复开卷受书哉所谓饶之适足以败之者也。 “自有天性好古，心悦艺文。 学不为禄，味道忘贫，若法高卿周生烈者。 学精不仕(疑有脱文)徇乎荣利者，万之一耳。 至於宁越倪宽黄霸之徒，所以强自笃励於典籍者，非天性也，皆由患苦困瘁，欲以经术自拔耳。 向使非汉武之世，则朱买臣严助之属，亦未必读书也。 今若取富贵之道，幸有易於学者，而复素无自然之好，岂肯复空自勤苦，执洒埽为诸生，远行寻师问道者乎 兵兴之世，武贵文寝，俗人视儒士如仆虏，见经诰如芥壤者，何哉由於声名背乎此也。 夫不用譬犹售章甫於夷越，徇髯蛇於华夏矣。 今若遐迩一例，明考课试，则必多负笈千里，以寻师友，转其礼赂之费，以买记籍者，不俟终日矣。 ” 抱朴子曰：才学之士堪秀孝者，已不可多得矣。 就令其人若桓灵之世，举吏不先以财货，便安台阁主者，则虽诸经兼本解，於问无不对，犹见诬枉，使不得过矣。 常追恨於时执事，不重为之防。 余意谓新年当试贡举者，今年便可使儒官才士，豫作诸策，计足周用。 集上禁其留草殿中，封闭之； 临试之时，亟赋之。 人事因缘於是绝。 当答策者，皆可会着一处，高选台省之官亲监察之。 又严禁其交关出入，毕事乃遣。 违犯有罪无赦。 如此，属托之翼窒矣。 夫明君恃己之不可欺，不恃人之不欺己也。 亦何耻於峻为斯制乎若试经法立，则天下可以不立学官，而人自勤乐矣。 案四科亦有明解法令之状，今在职之人，官无大小，悉不知法令。 或有微言难晓，而小吏多顽，而使之决狱，无以死生委之，以轻百姓之命，付无知之人也。 作官长不知法，为下吏所欺而不知，又决其口笔者，愤愤不能知食法，与不食不问，不以付主者。 或以意断事，蹉跌不慎法令，亦可令廉良之吏，皆取明律令者试之如试经，高者随才品叙用。 如此，天下必少弄法之吏，失理之狱矣。 交际卷第十六 抱朴子曰：余以朋友之交，不宜浮杂。 面而不心，扬雄攸讥。 故虽位显名美，门齐年敌，而趋舍异规，业尚乖互者，未尝结焉。 或有矜其先达，步高视远，或遗忽陵迟之旧好，或简弃后门之类味，或取人以官而不论德，其不遭知己，零沦丘园者，虽才深智远，操清节高者，不可也； 其进趋偶合，位显官通者，虽面墙庸琐，必及也。 如此之徒，虽能令壤虫云飞，斥鴳戾天，手捉刀尺，口为祸福，得之则排冰吐华，失之则当春凋悴，余代其口止叔口止脊，耻与共世。 穷之与达，不能求也。

Ge Hong replies: "Now that all under heaven is unified and the nine regions share the same customs, the royal institutions and government decrees should truly be uniform. Even with small measuring tools like scales and measures, one cannot allow them to vary from place to place—how much less can the standards for scholars and officials be left unchecked and inconsistent? Though the lands south of the Yangtze lie distant, bordering the sea’s edge, they have long been steeped in the Dao and transformed by culture, following ritual and teaching for over a thousand years. In the past, though briefly separated for less than a hundred years, the pursuit of Confucian learning was never entirely abandoned. Only because their territory is smaller than the Central Plains are the numbers of their scholars not equal in size. Yet among those of lofty virtue, talent, and learning, figures like Ziyou and Zhongren are by no means inferior to those of the central states. When the lands of Wu first submitted, their tribute scholars were dismissed without examination. Now, with peace nearly forty years established, they are still not examined—this is why the Confucian learning of the southeast has declined compared to former times. This is to treat them as akin to those in left-lapped robes, not to distinguish them. Moreover, even a gentleman treats others with ritual—how much more should those who are their joyful and kind parents do so! Laws that invite trouble and decrees that harm transformation—this is precisely what they do.

If tribute scholars are no longer examined, they will surely all engage in ostentatious pursuit of empty reputation—who would still open books to study? This is what is meant by ‘enriching them only to ruin them.’ Some are born with a love for antiquity, their hearts delighting in arts and letters. They study not for salary, savoring the Dao and forgetting poverty—like Fa Gaoqing and Zhou Shenglie. Those whose learning is profound yet do not serve (text may be missing) for the sake of glory and profit are one in ten thousand. As for figures like Ning Yue, Ni Kuan, and Huang Ba, their diligent self-exhortation in the classics was not due to innate nature but arose from hardship and suffering, seeking to elevate themselves through classical arts. Had it not been for the age of Emperor Wu of Han, even men like Zhu Maichen and Yan Zhu would not have read books. Now, if the path to wealth and honor happens to be easier than scholarship, and one lacks a natural inclination for learning, who would willingly endure hardship, sweeping floors as a student, traveling far to seek teachers and inquire of the Dao?

In times of war, the martial is prized and the civil declines. Common folk view scholars as servants and slaves, seeing the classics as worthless—why? Because fame and reputation have turned away from them. To do so is like selling *zhangfu* hats to the Yi and Yue or offering beards and snakes to the Central States. Now, if distant and near are treated equally, with clear examinations and assessments, many will surely carry their satchels a thousand *li* to seek teachers and friends, redirecting the costs of gifts and bribes to purchase books and records—this will not take a full day.

Ge Hong says: Talented and learned scholars capable of passing the *xiao* and *xian* examinations are already rare. Even if, as in the reigns of Emperors Huan and Ling, officials were not selected first by wealth but by those who preside over the imperial secretariat, then even if one mastered all the classics with full comprehension and answered every question flawlessly, they would still be slandered and obstructed, unable to advance. I have long regretted that those in power did not take greater precautions. My opinion is that for those who will be examined in the new year, this year the court should have erudite officials and talented scholars prepare examination questions in advance, ensuring they are sufficient for use. Gather them in the palace, forbid drafts from being kept, and seal them. When the time comes for the examination, distribute them swiftly. Thus, personal connections and favors will be cut off. Those answering the questions should all be assembled in one place, with high-ranking officials from the central offices personally overseeing them. Strictly prohibit any communication or movement, and only dismiss them when the examination is complete. Violations should be punished without pardon. In this way, the wings of favoritism and nepotism will be clipped.

A wise ruler relies on his own incorruptibility, not on others not deceiving him. Why should he feel shame in strictly enforcing such measures? If the examination system is established, then the empire need not establish official schools, and people will naturally strive and delight in learning. The four categories of officials also include those who clearly understand laws and decrees. Yet today, those in office, regardless of rank, are entirely ignorant of the law. Some legal terms are obscure and difficult to grasp, while petty officials are often dull-witted. To entrust them with deciding cases is to entrust life and death to them, to treat the lives of the common people lightly, and to hand them over to the ignorant. If an official does not know the law, he will be deceived by his subordinates without realizing it. When rendering judgments, if he is muddled and unable to understand the law, or if he does not apply it and leaves it to others, or if he decides cases by whim and errs by not carefully following the law, then even upright and capable officials should be tested on their knowledge of laws and decrees, as with the examination of the classics. Those who score highly should be appointed according to their talent and rank. In this way, the empire will surely have fewer officials who manipulate the law and fewer unjust cases.

Friends and Acquaintances, Scroll Sixteen

Ge Hong says: In friendships, one should not be indiscriminate. To be insincere in heart while maintaining appearances—this is what Yang Xiong criticized. Thus, even if one holds a high position, enjoys a fine reputation, shares the same gate, or is of similar age, if their aims and conduct differ, if their pursuits and values diverge, I have never formed ties with them. Some boast of their seniority, striding high and gazing far, or neglect and slight old friends who have declined, or dismiss those of humble origins and lesser status. Some judge others by rank rather than virtue. Those who do not encounter a true understanding friend, who languish in obscurity, even if their talent runs deep, their wisdom far-reaching, their conduct pure, and their integrity lofty, cannot succeed. Meanwhile, those whose advancement is merely coincidental, whose positions are prominent and offices prosperous, even if they are as ignorant as a wall or as mediocre as a fool, will surely rise. Such people, though they may cause insects to soar like clouds or sparrows to reach the heavens, wielding power like a blade and deciding fortune and misfortune with their words—when they favor you, they bloom like ice melting into flowers; when they abandon you, they wither like spring’s end. I would rather silence my tongue and turn my back on them, ashamed to share the world with such men. Whether one is impoverished or successful, one cannot seek them out."

chunks.original_text: 然而轻薄之人，无分之子，曾无疾非俄然之节，星言宵征，守其门廷，翕然谄笑，卑辞悦色，提壶执贽，时行索媚； 勤苦积久，犹见嫌拒，乃行因托长者以构合之。 其见受也，则踊悦过於幽系之遇赦； 其不合也，则懊悴剧於丧病之逮己也。 通塞有命，道贵正直，否泰付之自然，津途何足多咨。 嗟乎细人，岂不鄙哉！ 人情不同，一何远邪每为慨然，助彼羞之。 昔庄周见惠子从车之多，而弃其余鱼。 余感俗士(或脱“无”)不汲汲於攀及至也。 瞻彼云云，驰骋风尘者，不懋建德业，务本求己，而偏徇高交，以结朋党，谓人理莫比之要，当世莫此之急也。 以岳峙独立者，为涩吝疏拙； 以奴颜婢睐者，为晓解当世。 风成俗习，莫不逐末，流遁遂往，可慨者也。 或有德薄位高，器盈志溢，闻财利则惊掉，见奇士则坐睡。 褴缕杖策，被褐负笈者，虽文艳相雄，学优融玄，同之埃芥，不加接引。 若夫程郑王孙罗裒之徒，乘肥衣轻，怀金挟玉者，虽笔不集札，菽麦不分辩，为之倒屣，吐食握发。 余徒恨不在其位，有斧无柯，无以为国家流秽浊於四裔，投畀於有北。 彼虽赫奕，刀尺决乎(有脱文)势力足以移山拔海，吹呼能令泥象登云，造其门庭，我则未暇也。 而多有下意怡颜，匍匐膝进，求交於若人，以图其益。 悲夫！ 生民用心之不钧，何其辽邈之不肖也哉！ 余所以同生圣世而抱困贱，本后顾而不见者，今皆追瞻而不及，岂不有以乎！ 然性苟不堪，各从所好，以此存亡，予不能易也。 或又难曰：“时移世变，古今别务，行立乎己，名成乎人。 金玉经於不测者，托於轻舟也； 灵乌萃於玄霄者，扶摇之力也； 芳兰之芬烈者，清风之功也； 屈士起於丘园者，知己之助也。 今先生所交必清澄其行业，所厚必沙汰其心性，孑然只口止寺，失弃名辈，结雠一世，招怨流俗，岂合和光以笼物，同法之高义乎若比智而交，则白屋不降公旦之贵； 若钧才而游，则尼父必无入室之客矣。 ”
chunks.translated_text:
Yet these frivolous and unworthy men, those without distinction, lacking even the fleeting resolve to correct their faults, hasten through the night as if chasing stars, lingering at the gates of the powerful. With obsequious smiles and fawning words, they lower themselves in countenance, bearing jugs of wine and gifts of silk, ever seeking favor. Though they toil long and endure hardship, they are still met with disdain and rejection. Thus, they resort to currying the favor of elders to forge connections. When their advances are accepted, their joy surpasses even that of a prisoner granted amnesty; when rebuffed, their despair exceeds the grief of one struck by illness or bereavement.

Success and failure are decreed by fate, and the Dao prizes uprightness. Prosperity and adversity are left to nature—why then obsess over the paths of advancement? Alas, such petty men! How base they are! Human nature differs so widely—how far apart we stand! Each time I witness this, I cannot help but feel indignation on their behalf.

Once, Zhuang Zhou, seeing the vast retinue of Hui Zi, abandoned the fish he had yet to eat. I, too, lament that worldly men do not strive earnestly for true attainment. Beholding those who gallop through the dust of the world, I see them not laboring to establish virtue or cultivate their own foundations, but instead chasing high connections to form cliques, believing no principle more vital, no urgency greater in this age. Those who stand tall and independent like a mountain are dismissed as stingy and inept; those who grovel with the demeanor of slaves are praised as astute and worldly-wise. Such customs, once formed, spread like wind—none pursue the root, and all drift ever further. How lamentable!

Some, though of meager virtue, occupy lofty positions, their capacities overflowing with ambition. At the mention of wealth or profit, they startle as if shaken; at the sight of extraordinary men, they feign sleep. Yet those who lean on staffs in tattered robes, bearing satchels of books—though their words shine like jewels and their learning delves into the profound—are treated as dust or weeds, never welcomed. But when the likes of Cheng Zheng or the scions of Wangsun, clad in fine robes and riding sleek carriages, their hands heavy with gold and jade, appear—though they cannot wield a brush to compose a letter or distinguish beans from wheat—they are met with haste, shoes discarded, meals spat out, hair grasped in urgency.

I only regret that I do not hold office, for though I have an axe, I lack the handle—powerless to purge the filth of the state, to cast its corruption to the farthest reaches or banish it to the northern wastes. Those men, though resplendent, wield blades that decide all—with power enough to move mountains and uproot seas, their breath alone can lift clay idols to the clouds. Yet when they stand at my gate, I have no time for them. And still, many lower themselves, forcing smiles, crawling forward on their knees, seeking their favor for some imagined gain. How tragic! The hearts of men are so uneven—how vast the gulf between them and true worth!

This is why, though born in a sagely age, I remain mired in obscurity and lowliness. Those I once looked back upon and saw no more, I now gaze after in vain—how could it be otherwise? Yet if my nature cannot endure it, I shall follow my own inclinations. In this, I cannot be swayed, whether it leads to survival or ruin.

Some may object: *"Times change, and the world with them; the duties of past and present differ. Conduct is established by oneself, but reputation is shaped by others. Gold and jade endure the unfathomable because they rest in a light boat; the sacred bird alights in the dark heavens by the power of the whirlwind; the fragrance of orchids is spread by the pure breeze; and the recluse rises from obscurity through the aid of a true friend. Now, sir, you choose friends only from those whose conduct is pure and whose deeds are clear, favoring only those whose hearts have been sifted and refined. Alone, silent, and secluded, you cast aside your peers, make enemies of the age, and provoke the scorn of common custom. Is this not at odds with the lofty principle of harmonizing with the world while preserving one’s light? If one were to befriend only the wise, then even the humble cottage would not welcome the noble Duke of Zhou; if one were to associate only with equals in talent, then Confucius himself would have no disciples to enter his chamber."*

chunks.original_text: 抱朴子曰：“吾闻详交者不失人，而泛结者多后悔。 故曩哲先择而后交，不先交而后择也。 子之所论，出人之计也； 吾之所守，退士之志也。 子云玉浮鸟高，皆有所因，诚复别理一家之说也。 吾以为宁作不载之宝，不飞之鹏，不飏之兰，无党之士，亦(何)损於夜光之质，垂天之大，含芳之卉，不朽之兰乎且夫名多其实，位过其才，处之者犹鲜免於祸辱，交之者何足以为荣福哉！ “由兹论之，则交彼而遇者，虽得达不足贵； 芘之而误者，譬如荫朽树之被笮也。 彼尚不能自止其颠蹶，亦安能救我之碎首哉！ 吾闻大丈夫之自得而外物者，其於庸人也，盖逼迫不获已而与之形接，虽以千计，犹蚤虱之积乎衣，而赘疣之攒乎体也。 失之虽以万数，犹飞尘之去嵩岱，邓林之堕朽条耳。 岂以有之为益，无之觉损乎 “且夫朋友也者，必取乎直谅多闻，拾遗斥谬，生无请言，死无托辞，终始一契，寒暑不渝者。 然而此人良未易得，而或默语殊途，或憎爱异心，或盛合衰离，或见利忘信。 其处今也，璧犹禽鱼之结侣，冰炭之同器，欲其久合，安可得哉！ 夫父子天性，好恶宜钧，而子政子骏，平论异隔； 南山伯奇，辩讼有无。 面别心殊，其来尚矣。 总而混之，不亦难哉！ “世俗之人，交不论志，逐名趋势，热来冷去； 见过不改，视迷不救； 有利则独专而不相分，有害则苟免而不相恤； 或事便则先取而不让，值机会则卖彼以安此。 凡如是，则有不如无也。 “天下不为尽不中交也，率於为益者寡而生累者众。 知人之明，上圣所难。 而欲力厉近才，短於鉴物者，务广其交，又欲使悉得，可与经夷险而不易情，历危苦而相负荷者，吾未见其可多得也。 虽搜琬琰於培蝼之上，索鸾凤乎鹪鹩之巢，未为难也。 吾亦岂敢谓蓝田之阳，丹穴之中，为无此物哉！ 亦直言其稀已矣。 “夫操尚不同，犹金沈羽浮也。 志好之乖次，犹火升而水降也。 苟不可同，虽造化之灵，大块之匠，不可使同也，何可强乎！ 余所禀讷马矣，加之以天挺笃懒，诸戏弄之事，弹棋博弈，皆所恶见； 及飞轻走迅，游猎傲览，咸所不为，殊不喜嘲亵。 凡此数者，皆时世所好，莫不耽之，而余悉阙焉，故亲交所以尤辽也。 加以挟直，好吐忠荩，药石所集，甘心者鲜。 又欲勉之以学问，谏之以驰竞，止其樗蒲，节其沈湎，此又常人所不能悦也。 “毁方瓦合，违情偶俗，人之爱力，甚所不堪，而欲好日新，安可得哉！ 知其如此而不辩改之，可不谓之暗於当世，拙於用大乎夫交而不卒，合而又离，则两受不弘之名，俱失克终之美。 夫厚则亲爱生焉，薄则嫌隙结焉，自然之理也，可不详择乎！ 为可临觞者拊背，执手须臾，欲多其数而必其全，吾所惧也。 ” 或曰：“然则都可以无交乎”
chunks.translated_text:
Bao Puzi replied: "I have heard that those who choose friends with care do not lose true companions, while those who form bonds indiscriminately often come to regret it. Thus, the sages of old first selected and then befriended, never first befriended and then selected. Your argument, sir, is a calculation for worldly success; my resolve is the aspiration of a retiring scholar. You say that jade floats and birds soar only by some agency—this is indeed a separate doctrine of its own. Yet I would rather be an untransported treasure, an earthbound roc, an unscented orchid, a man without faction—what loss is there in being a luminous gem, a creature of boundless wings, a fragrant blossom, an undying orchid?

Moreover, when a man’s reputation exceeds his substance or his rank surpasses his talent, even he who holds such a position seldom escapes calamity and disgrace—how then can befriending him bring honor or fortune? By this reasoning, to associate with one who prospers by chance is no true achievement, even if he attains success; while to cling to one who errs is like seeking shelter beneath a rotten tree—when it collapses, how can it save me from a shattered skull?

I have heard that the true gentleman, content in himself and indifferent to externals, regards the common run of men as though forced into fleeting contact with them. Though they number in the thousands, they are but fleas and lice clinging to his robes, warts and growths upon his body. Though they depart by the tens of thousands, they vanish like dust blown from Mount Song, like withered branches falling from Deng Forest. How can their presence bring gain, or their absence be felt as loss?

As for friendship, it must be founded upon those who are upright, trustworthy, and learned—who correct one’s errors and rebuke one’s faults, who speak no flattery in life and make no excuses in death, whose bond remains unbroken through all seasons. Yet such men are not easily found. Some diverge in speech and silence, others differ in love and hate; some unite in prosperity and part in adversity, while others forget loyalty when profit beckons. In their present state, they are like jade and fish forming a fellowship, like ice and charcoal sharing a vessel—how can such unions endure?

Even father and son, bound by nature and sharing the same inclinations, may yet disagree: Zizheng and Zijun held opposing views, while Boqi of Nanshan was forced to plead his case. That men’s faces differ while their hearts diverge is an ancient truth. To lump them all together—is this not difficult indeed?

The common run of men form friendships without regard for shared purpose, chasing fame and following power, warm in approach and cold in departure. They overlook faults and ignore delusion; when profit arises, they seize it alone without sharing; when harm comes, they flee without a thought for others. When opportunity favors them, they take precedence without yielding; when crisis strikes, they betray others to save themselves. In such cases, having such friends is worse than having none.

Not all in the world are unworthy of friendship—yet those who bring benefit are few, while those who bring trouble are many. The discernment to know men is a gift even the greatest sages find difficult. Yet those of limited talent, lacking in judgment, strive to broaden their circle of friends, hoping all will prove steadfast through peril and adversity, bearing each other’s burdens through hardship. I have never seen such abundance. It would be easier to seek flawless jade upon an anthill or phoenixes in the nest of a wren.

I do not dare claim that in the southern slopes of Lantian or the depths of Danxue, no such men exist—only that they are rare indeed. When principles differ, gold sinks while feathers float; when aspirations clash, fire rises while water descends. If they cannot be aligned, not even the Creator or the Craftsman of Nature can make them so—how then can they be forced?

My nature is as dull as a plodding horse, compounded by a heaven-sent indolence. Games of skill—board and dice—I despise; swift rides, hunting, and idle roaming—I do not pursue. I have no taste for jest or vulgarity. These are the very things the age delights in, yet I lack them all, which is why my close friendships are so few. Moreover, I cling to honesty and freely speak my loyal counsel, drawing the bitter medicine of reproof, which few willingly accept. I urge others to study and warn them against reckless ambition, discourage gambling, and curb their excesses—these are things most men cannot abide.

To cast aside one’s true nature to conform to the world, to force oneself to please others—this is a burden I cannot bear. Yet if one knows this and does not change, can one not be called blind to the times and inept in great matters? Friendships that do not endure, alliances that dissolve—both parties earn a reputation for inconstancy and lose the beauty of a perfect end. Where there is depth, affection arises; where there is shallowness, resentment takes root. This is the natural principle—can one not choose with care? To clap a man on the back over wine, to clasp his hand for a moment, to seek quantity while demanding perfection—this is what I fear."

Someone asked: "Then should one have no friends at all?"

If one were to befriend only the wise, then even the humble cottage would not welcome the noble Duke of Zhou; if one were to associate only with equals in talent, then Confucius himself would have no disciples to enter his chamber."*

chunks.original_text: 抱朴子答曰：“何其然哉！ 夫畏水者何必废舟楫，忌伤者何必弃父斤交之为道，其来尚矣。 天地不交则不泰，上下不交即乖志。 夫不泰则二气隔并矣，志乖则天下无国矣。 然始之甚易，终之竟难。 患乎所结非其人，败於争小以忘大也。 《易》美多兰，《诗》咏百朋，虽有兄弟，不如友生。 切思三益，大圣所嘉，门人所以增亲，恶言所以不至； 管仲所以免诛戮而立霸功，子元所以去亭长而驱朱轩者，交之力也。 “单弦不能发《韶》《夏》之和音，孑色不能成兖龙之玮烨，一味不能合伊鼎之甘，独木不能致邓林之茂。 玄圃极天，盖由众石之积。 南溟浩漾，实须群流之赴。 明镜举则倾冠见矣，羲和照则曲影觉矣，檃括修则枉刺之疾消矣，良友结则辅仁之道弘矣。 达者知其然也，所企及则必简乎胜己，所降结则必料乎同志。 其处也则讲道进德，其出也则齐心比翼。 否则钧鱼钓之业，泰则协经世之务。 安则有以精义，危则有以相恤。 耻令谭肯专面地之笃，不使王贡擅弹冠之美。 夫然，故交道可贵也。 “然实未易知，势利生去就，积毁坏刎颈之契，渐渍释胶漆之坚。 於是有忘素情之惆叹，或睚眦而不思，遂令元伯巨卿之好，独着於昔； 张耳陈余之变，屡构於今。 推往寻来，良可叹也。 夫梧禽不与鸱枭同枝，麟虞不与豺狼连群，清源不与浊潦混流，仁明不与凶暗同处。 何者渐染积而移直道，暴迫则生害也。 ” 或人曰：“敢问全交之道可得闻乎” 抱朴子答曰：“君子交绝犹无恶言，岂肯向所异辞乎杀身犹以许友，岂名位之足竞乎善交狎而不慢，和而不同，见彼有失，则正色而谏之； 告我以过，则速改而惮。 不以忤彼心而不言，不以逆我耳而不纳，不以巧辩饰其非，不以华辞文其失，不形同而神乖，不若情而口合，不面从而背憎，不疾人之胜己，护其短而引其长，隐其失而宣其得，外无计数之诤，内遗心竞之累。 夫然后《鹿鸣》之好全，而《伐木》之刺息。 若乃轻合而不重离，易厚而不难薄，始如形影，终为叁辰，至欢变为笃恨，接援化成雠敌，不详之悔，亦无以(原有脱文)。 往者汉季陵迟，皇辔不振，在公之义替，纷竞之俗成。 以违时为清高，以救世为辱身。 尊卑礼坏，大伦遂乱。 在位之人，不务尽节，委本趋末，背实寻声。 王事废者其誉美，奸过积者其功多。 莫不飞轮兼策，星言假寐，冒寒触暑，以走权门，市虚华之名於秉势之口，买非分之位於卖官之家。 或争所欲，还相屠灭。 於是公叔伟长疾其若彼，力不能正，不忍见之，尔乃发愤着论，杜门绝交，斯诚感激有为而然。 盖矫枉而过正，非经常之永训也。 徒当远非类之党，慎谄黩之源。 何必裸袒以诡彼己，断粒以刺玉食哉！ 夫交之为非，重谏而不止，遂至大乱。 故礼义之所弃，可以绝矣。 备阙卷第十七 抱朴子曰：騕褭能奋兰筋以绝景，而不能履冰以乘深； 猛虎能似雷霆以博噬，而不能踊云雾以凌虚。 鸿鹍不能振翅於笼罩之中，轻鹞不能电击於几筵之下。 物既然矣，人亦如之。 故能调和阴阳者，未必能兼百行修简书也； 能敷五迈九者，不必能全小洁经曲碎也。 惠子，上相之标也，而不能役舟楫以凌阳侯； 汉高，神武之杰也，而不能治产业端检括；
chunks.translated_text:
Bao Puzi replied: "How can this be so! Those who fear water need not abandon boats and oars, nor must those who dread injury forsake the adze and axe. The Way of friendship has endured since antiquity. If heaven and earth do not commune, they cannot achieve harmony; if superiors and inferiors do not commune, their aspirations diverge. Without harmony, the two qi remain divided; with divergent aspirations, the world has no states. Yet while beginnings are easy, endings prove difficult. The danger lies in forming bonds with the wrong person, or ruining great matters over petty disputes.

The *Book of Changes* praises the multitude of orchids, and the *Book of Songs* extols a hundred strings of cowries. Though one may have brothers, they are not equal to friends. Earnestly seeking the Three Benefits—praised by the great sages—strengthens the bonds between disciples and keeps slander at bay. It was through friendship that Guan Zhong avoided execution and established hegemony, and that Zi Yuan left his post as pavilion chief to ride in a vermilion carriage. Such is the power of fellowship.

A single string cannot produce the harmony of the *Shao* or *Xia* melodies; a lone hue cannot achieve the brilliance of dragon-scale brocade; one flavor cannot blend the sweetness of Yi’s tripod; a single tree cannot attain the lushness of Deng’s forest. The heights of the Dark Garden are built by the accumulation of countless stones; the vastness of the Southern Sea arises from the confluence of many streams. When a bright mirror is raised, a crooked cap is revealed; when Xihe’s light shines, a bent shadow is perceived; when the straightening board is applied, the ailment of crookedness is cured; when good friends unite, the Way of assisting virtue flourishes. The wise understand this: in their aspirations, they carefully choose those superior to themselves; in their associations, they deliberately seek those of like mind. At home, they discuss the Dao and cultivate virtue; abroad, they align their hearts and soar as one. Otherwise, they engage in the pursuits of fishing and hunting; at best, they collaborate in worldly affairs. In peace, they refine their understanding of principle; in peril, they support one another. They feel shame if Tan Ken monopolizes the virtue of steadfastness, and do not allow Wang and Gong to claim sole beauty in dusting their caps. Thus, the Way of friendship is to be cherished.

Yet true discernment is not easy. Power and profit breed fickleness; accumulated slander severs even neck-sworn pacts; gradual erosion dissolves the firmness of glue and lacquer. Hence the lament for forgotten bonds of old, or the refusal to overlook even a glance of resentment—so that the friendship of Yuan Bo and Ju Qing shines only in the past, while the betrayal of Zhang Er and Chen Yu repeats endlessly in the present. Reflecting on the past and examining the present, one cannot but sigh. The phoenix does not share a branch with the owl, the unicorn does not herd with wolves, clear springs do not mingle with muddy torrents, and the benevolent and wise do not dwell with the cruel and benighted. For gradual contamination corrupts the straight path, and coercion breeds harm."

Someone asked: "May I inquire about the Way of perfecting friendship?"

Bao Puzi replied: "When a gentleman severs a bond, he does so without malice—how could he then speak ill of a former friend? He would sacrifice himself for a friend’s sake—how could he compete over rank or status? In good fellowship, there is intimacy without disrespect, harmony without conformity. If a friend errs, he admonishes with solemn countenance; if told of his own faults, he swiftly corrects them without hesitation. He does not withhold counsel to avoid offending, nor reject advice because it grates on his ears. He does not use clever words to conceal wrongs, nor embellish faults with flowery speech. He does not feign agreement while his spirit rebels, nor pretend affection while his heart disagrees. He does not flatter to one’s face and resent behind their back, nor resent another’s superiority. He guards their shortcomings while drawing out their strengths, concealing their faults while proclaiming their virtues. Externally, he avoids petty disputes; internally, he sheds the burden of rivalry. Only then is the bond of the *Deer Cry* preserved, and the satire of the *Felling Trees* silenced.

But if one treats bonds lightly, valuing union but not separation, prizing depth but not difficulty in parting—beginning like shadow and form, ending like sun and moon—then the deepest joy turns to bitter enmity, and clasped hands become sworn foes. The regret of carelessness is beyond remedy.

In the past, during the decline of the Han, the imperial reins slackened, and the duty of public service faded while the custom of contention flourished. Defying the times was deemed lofty, while saving the world was seen as humiliation. The rites between high and low collapsed, and the great ethical order descended into chaos. Those in office did not strive to fulfill their duties but abandoned fundamentals for trivialities, forsaking substance for reputation. Those who neglected state affairs won praise, while those who amassed transgressions gained merit. All spurred their carriages and whipped their horses, traveling by starlight and resting only briefly, braving cold and heat to rush to the gates of the powerful. They traded empty glory for the words of the influential, and bought undeserved rank from those who sold office. Some, vying for their desires, turned to mutual destruction. Gongshu Wei, distressed by such a world and unable to set it right, could not bear to witness it—thus, in indignation, he wrote his treatise, shut his door, and severed all ties. This was indeed a passionate response to circumstances, but in overcorrecting, he strayed from the eternal lesson. One should merely distance oneself from unworthy factions and be cautious of the roots of flattery and corruption. Why go to extremes—baring one’s body to prove a point or starving oneself to rebuke luxury?

If friendship turns to harm despite earnest admonition, leading to great disorder, then it is right to abandon what rites and justice have already forsaken.

*Baopuzi*, Scroll Seventeen: "The swift steed can gallop across the plains with sinews like orchids, yet cannot tread upon ice to cross the deep; the fierce tiger can roar like thunder and rend its prey, yet cannot soar through clouds and mist to ascend the void. The great roc cannot flap its wings within a cage, nor can the nimble sparrowhawk strike like lightning beneath the banquet table. Things are thus, and so too are men. Therefore, one who can harmonize yin and yang may not necessarily master the hundred virtues or govern documents; one who can expound the Five Constants and Nine Virtues may not necessarily perfect minor purity or meticulous details. Hui Shi, paragon of prime ministers, could not command boats to brave the waves; Han Gaozu, peerless in martial spirit, could not manage his estate or maintain discipline."

Han Xin, foremost among fine generals, could not manage farming or commerce to stave off hunger and cold; Zhou Bo, stalwart pillar of the altars of state, could not account for grain and coin or adjudicate legal pleas. If one were to discard the long for the short, then talents peerless and preeminent would go unused; if one were to demand perfection and scrutinize petty proprieties, then the achievements of those who craft eras and succor the people would never be manifest.

Heaven cannot level its northwest, nor can earth raise its southeast; the sun and moon cannot cast their light into crooked caves, nor can the surging wind stir waves in the depths of a well. To pick one’s teeth, the finest pine or catalpa is no match for a single-inch toothpick; to clean one’s ears, the greatest beams are no better than a wren’s feather; to shoot birds, a thousand gold is no match for a pellet of mud; to sew and mend, a long sword is no match for a needle of a few inches.

Why must one harness a great elephant to catch a mouse, or fashion a roc to herald the dawn? Thus, Jiang Ziya sold warm broth yet found no buyers, yet was summoned as teacher by Kings Wen and Wu; Jiang Sheng was indolent and insolent in a hundred leagues, yet stood peerless beneath the Three Sophoras.

chunks.original_text: 抱朴子曰：华章藻蔚，非蒙瞍所玩； 英逸之才，非浅短所识。 夫瞻视不能接物，则兖龙与素褐同价矣； 聪鉴不足相涉，则俊民与庸夫一概矣。 眼不见，则美不入神焉； 莫之与，则伤之者至焉。 且夫爱憎好恶，古今不均，时移俗易，物同价异。 譬之夏后之璜，曩直连城，鬻之於今，贱於铜铁。 故昔以隐居求志为高士，今以山林之儒为不肖。 故圣世之良干，乃暗俗之罪人也； 往者之介洁，乃末叶之羸劣也。 弘伟之士，履道之生，其崇信匪徒重仞之墙，其渊泽不唯吕梁之深也，故短近不能赏，而浅促不能测焉。 因以异乎己而薄之矣，以不求我而疾之矣，不贵不用，何足言乎乃有播埃尘於白珪，生疮疒有於玉肌，讪疵雷同，攻伐独立，曾叁蒙劫剽之垢，巢许获穿窬之谤。 自匪明并悬象，玄鉴表微者，焉能披泥抽沦玉，澄川掇沈珠哉！ 夫珪璋居肆而不售，矧乃翳於盘璞乎奇士扣角而见遏，况乃潜於四羊薮乎 孙膑思骋其秘略，而司马刖之； 韩非愿建治绩，而李斯杀之； 贾谊慷慨，怀经国之术，而武夫排之； 子政忠良，有匡危之具，而恭显陷之。 和氏所以抱璞而泣血，禽息所以发愤而碎首也。 夫玉石易别於贤愚，爱宝情笃於好士，以易别之宝，合笃好之物，犹获罪截趾，历世受诬。 况乎难知之贤，非意所急，谗人画蛇足於无形，奸臣畏忠贞之害己，体曲者忌绳墨之容，夜裸者憎明烛之来。 是以高誉美行，抑而不扬，虚构之谤，先形生影。 又无楚人号哭之荐，万无一遇，固其宜矣。 夫以玉为石者，亦将以石为玉矣； 以贤为愚者，亦将以愚为贤者矣。 以石为玉，未有伤也； 以愚为贤者，亡之诊也。 盖诊亡者虽存而必亡，犹脉死者虽生而必死也。 可勿慎乎！ 於戏，悲夫！
chunks.translated_text:
The Master Embracing Simplicity said: Ornate compositions and florid prose are not for the blind to appreciate; talents of heroic and transcendent quality are not for the shallow and narrow-minded to recognize. If one’s gaze cannot reach the object, then a dragon’s robe and plain hemp will fetch the same price; if one’s discernment cannot penetrate the matter, then the outstanding and the mediocre will be judged alike. When the eye does not see, beauty does not enter the spirit; when none befriends, those who would harm draw near.

Moreover, love and hate, approval and disdain, have never been uniform across the ages. As times change and customs shift, the same things command different values. Take the jade tablet of the Xia sovereign: once it was worth several cities, yet if sold today, it would be cheaper than bronze or iron. Thus, in former times, those who withdrew to seek their Dao were deemed lofty scholars, while now those who dwell in mountain forests are deemed unworthy. Therefore, the worthy pillars of a sagely age become the criminals of a benighted generation; the integrity of the ancients becomes the feebleness of the latter days.

The man of grand and towering spirit, the life that treads the Way—his towering trust is not merely a wall of fathoms high, his profound beneficence is not merely the depth of Lüliang Gorge. Thus, the shortsighted and near cannot appreciate him, the shallow and hasty cannot fathom him. They despise him for being different from themselves, resent him for not seeking their favor, and so they neither value nor employ him—what more need be said?

Some cast dust upon white jade, raise sores upon jade-like skin, slander in unison, and attack the independent. They heap upon the worthy the filth of Meng Ben and the plunder of Jie Zitui, and slander Chao Fu and Xu You as thieves and burglars. Unless one possesses the luminous insight of the sun and moon, the dark discernment that reveals the subtle, how can one sift jade from mud, draw pearls from the depths of the river?

When fine jade lies unsold in the marketplace, how much less will it be recognized when veiled in uncut stone? When a remarkable man is halted at the sound of his zither, how much less will he be discovered when hidden in the thickets of the Four Rams? Sun Bin longed to deploy his secret strategies, yet Sima Qian had his feet cut off; Han Fei wished to establish governance, yet Li Si had him killed; Jia Yi was impassioned, harboring the art of ordering the state, yet was pushed aside by warriors; Liu Xiang was loyal and good, possessing the means to save a nation in peril, yet was ensnared by Hong and Xian.

This is why Bian He held his uncut jade and wept blood, why Qin Xi smashed his head in despair. Jade and stone are easily distinguished, yet the love for treasures is not as deep as the love for the worthy. Even when a treasure that is easy to distinguish is paired with a love that is profound, one still incurs punishment and mutilation, suffers slander for generations. How much more so for the worthy, who are difficult to know and not urgently sought after? Slanderers add feet to a snake that has no form; treacherous ministers fear the harm that loyalty and integrity bring to themselves; the crooked resent the straightness of the marking line; those who strip at night hate the coming of the bright candle.

Thus, lofty reputations and fine conduct are suppressed and not extolled, while groundless slander takes shape before its shadow. Without a man of Chu to wail and recommend, there is not one chance in ten thousand of encountering recognition—this is only to be expected. He who takes jade for stone will also take stone for jade; he who takes the worthy for fools will also take fools for the worthy. To take stone for jade does no harm; to take fools for the worthy is the diagnosis of ruin.

For ruin, though it may seem to exist, is already doomed, just as a pulse that is dead, though the body lives, is already fated to die. Can one not be cautious? Alas, how lamentable!

chunks.original_text: 莫之思者也。 昔仲尼上圣也，东受累於齐人，南见塞於子西。 文种大贤也，初不齿於荆俗，末雍游於钧如。 竞年立功，不亦难乎夫结绿玄黎，非陶猗不能市也； 千钧之重，非贲获不能抱也。 《白雪》之弦，非灵素不能徽也； 迈伦之才，非明主不能用也。 然耀灵光夜之珍，不为莫求而亏其质，以苟且於贱贾； 洪锺周鼎(或有脱文)，不为委沦而轻其体，取见举於侏儒； 峄阳云和，不为不御而息唱，以竞显於淫哇； 冠群之德，不以沈抑而履径，而剸节於流俗。 是以和璧变为滞货，柔木废於勿用，赤刀之矿，不得经欧冶之炉； 元凯之畴，终不值四门之辟也。 任命卷第十九
chunks.translated_text:
Those who do not ponder this are such. Of old, Confucius, the supreme sage, was entangled by the men of Qi in the east and blocked by Zixi in the south. Wen Zhong, a man of great worth, was at first not esteemed by the customs of Jing, and in the end was leisurely executed like a common criminal. To establish merit in the span of a lifetime—is this not difficult indeed?

Jade like *jielü* and *xuanli* cannot be purchased without the wealth of Tao or Yi; a weight of a thousand *jun* cannot be lifted without the strength of Meng Ben or Wu Huo. The strings of *Bai Xue* cannot be tuned without the skill of Ling Su; talents like those of Mao Lun cannot be employed without an enlightened lord.

Yet luminous treasures of the night do not diminish their essence to sell cheaply for want of buyers; great bells and Zhou tripods do not lighten their weight to be lifted by dwarfs though cast aside; the zithers of Yiyang and Yunhe do not cease their song to vie for fame in lewd tunes; and virtues that surpass the multitude do not tread crooked paths in obscurity nor sever their integrity to follow vulgar ways.

Thus, the *he* jade becomes unsellable goods; supple wood is discarded as useless; the ore of the Red Blade never enters the furnace of Ou Ye; and the company of the Eight Elemental Worthies never gains entry through the Four Gates.

chunks.original_text: 抱朴子曰：余之友人有居泠先生者，恬愉静素，形神相忘，外不饰惊愚之容，内不寄有容之心，游精坟诰，乐以忘忧。 昼竞羲和之末景，夕照望舒之余耀，道靡远而不究，言无微而不研。 然车迹不轫权右之国，尺牍不经贵势之庭。 是以名不出蓬户，身不离畎亩。 於是翼亮大夫候而难之曰：“余闻渊蟠起则玄云赴，道化雨沾则逸才奋。 故康衢有角歌之音，鼎俎发凌风之迹。 沽之则收不赀之贾，踊之则超在天之举。 耀逸景於旸谷，播大明乎九垓。 勋荫当世，声扬罔极。 故寻仞之途甚近而弗往者，虽追风之脚不能到也； 楹棁之下至卑而不动者，虽鸿鹍之翅未之及也。 况乎寝足於大荒之表，敛羽於幽梧之枝，安得效迅以寻景，振轻乎苍霄哉 年期奄冉而不久，托世飘迅而不再，智者履霜则知坚冰之必至，处始则悟生物之有终。 六龙促轨於大浑，华颠倏忽而告暮，古人所以映顺流而顾叹，眄过隙而兴悲矣。 先生资命世之逸量，含英伟以邈俗，锐翰汪濊以波涌，六奇抑郁而渊蓄； 然不能凌扶摇以高竦，扬清耀於九玄，器不陈於瑚簋之末，体不免於负薪之劳，犹奏和音於聋俗之地，鬻章甫於被发之域。 徒忘寤於翰林，锐意以穷神，崇琬琰於怀抱之内，吐琳琅於毛墨之端，躬困屡空之俭，神劳坚高之间，譬若埋尺璧於重壤之下，封文锦於沓匮之中，终无交易之富，孰赏堙翳之珍哉 “夫龙骥维絷，则无以别乎蹇驴； 赤刀韬锋，则曷用异於铅刃。 鳣鲔不居牛迹，大鹏不滞蒿林。 愿先生委龙蛇之穴，升利见之途，释户庭之独洁，览二鼠而远寤，越穷谷以登高，袭丹藻以改素，竞惊飚於清晨，不盘旋以错度，收名器於崇高，响锺鼎之庆祚。 柏成一介之夫，辨薇可足多慕乎” 居泠先生应曰：“盖闻灵机冥缅，混芒眇昧，祸福交错乎倚伏之间，兴亡缠绵乎盈虚之会； 迅游者不能脱逐身之景，乐成者不能免理致之败； 匡流末者，未若挺治乎无兆之中； 整已然者，不逮反本乎玄朴之外。 是以觉蠖者，甘屈以保伸； 识通塞者，不惨悦於否泰。 且夫洪陶范物，大象流形，躁静异尚，翔沈舛情。 金宝其重，羽矜其轻。 笃隘者执束於滓涅达妙者逍遥於玄清。 潢洿纳行潦而潘溢，渤澥吞百川而不盈。 鲉虾踊悦於泥泞，赤螭凌厉乎高冥。 嚼香饵者，快嗜欲而赴死； 味虚淡者，含天和而趋生； 识机神者，瞻无兆而弗惑； 暗休咎者，触强弩而不惊。 各附攸好，安肯改营 “吾闻五玉不能自剖於嵩岫，腾蛇不能无雾而电征，龙渊不能勿操而断犀兕，景锺不能莫扣而扬洪声。 金芝须商风而激耀，仓庚俟烟火日皿而修鸣，骐騄不苟驰以赴险，君子不诡遇以毁名。 运屯则沈沦於勿用，时行则高竦乎天庭。 士以自炫为不高，女以自媒为不贞。 何必委洗耳之峻标，效负俎之干荣哉 夫其穷也，则有虞婆娑而陶钓，尚父见逐於愚妪，范生来辱於溺篑，弘式匿奇於耕牧； 及其达也，则淮阴投竿而称孤，文种解尸彳乔而纡青，傅说释筑而论道，管子脱桎为上卿。 盖君子藏器以有待也，蓄德以有为也，非其时不见也，非其君不事也，穷达任所值，出处无所系。 其静也，则为逸民之宗； 其动也，则为元凯之表。 或运思於立言，或铭勋乎国器。 殊途同归，其致一焉。
chunks.translated_text:
Gezhu said: Among my friends there was one known as Master Juling, serene and untroubled, his form and spirit in perfect forgetfulness. Outwardly, he did not adorn himself with the guise of startling the foolish; inwardly, he harbored no mind to accommodate others. His spirit roamed the ancient canons, finding joy that banished care. By day, he pursued the last rays of Xihe; by evening, he basked in the lingering glow of Wangshu. The Dao, however distant, he exhaustively explored; no word, however subtle, did he fail to scrutinize.

Yet his carriage left no tracks in the lands of the powerful, and his letters never crossed the thresholds of the eminent. Thus, his name never passed beyond his thatched door, nor did his person stray from the furrows of his fields.

Then Yiliang the Grand Master approached and challenged him, saying: “I have heard that when the coiled dragon stirs, dark clouds gather; when the Dao rains transformation, hidden talents arise. Thus, the broad streets resound with the songs of unicorns, and the tripods and cauldrons reveal the traces of soaring winds. To sell such gifts is to reap boundless reward; to leap with them is to ascend beyond the heavens. Their radiance illumines the Valley of Sunrise, their brilliance spreads through the Nine Realms. Their merit shades the age, their fame echoes without end.

Yet he who does not tread the path of a mere fathom’s length, though swift as the wind, cannot reach its end; he who does not stir from beneath the rafters, though his wings be those of the great roc, cannot attain the heights. How much less can one who buries his feet in the outer wilds, who folds his wings on the branches of secluded Wu, hope to match swiftness with the sun’s shadow or soar lightly through the azure vault?

The years pass swiftly and do not return; life in this world is fleeting and never repeats. The wise, treading frost, know that solid ice must follow; dwelling in beginnings, they perceive that all living things must end. The Six Dragons hasten their course through the great chaos; hoary heads swiftly announce the approach of dusk. This is why the ancients, gazing at the flowing stream, sighed in reflection, and casting their eyes upon the passing crack, grieved.

You, sir, possess a talent surpassing the age, containing within you a grandeur that transcends the vulgar. Your brush flows vast and deep as surging waves; your sixfold marvels lie pent in profound reserve. Yet you cannot ride the whirlwind to towering heights, nor display your purity in the Nine Mysteries. Your vessel remains unpresented at the ends of ritual vessels; your person is not spared the toil of bearing firewood. You offer harmonious notes in a land of the deaf, peddle ceremonial caps among the bareheaded. In vain do you forget sleep in the forest of brushes, striving to fathom the divine; in vain do you cherish jade within your breast, pour forth gem-like words from your brush’s tip. Your body suffers the hardship of repeated want; your spirit labors amid lofty and unyielding heights. It is as if you buried a foot-long jade beneath deep soil, or sealed brocade in a sealed chest—never to gain wealth through exchange, who will appreciate such buried treasures?

When the dragon and the steed are fettered, how do they differ from the lame donkey? When the Red Blade sheathes its edge, how does it surpass a leaden knife? The great sturgeon does not dwell in ox-tracks; the roc does not linger in the brushwood. I hope, sir, that you will forsake the dragon’s den, ascend the path of clear advantage, abandon the solitary purity of your door and courtyard, observe the two mice and awaken to distant truths, cross the barren valley to climb the heights, don the crimson robes and cast off plainness. Compete with the morning’s swift winds, do not linger or err in your course. Gather your name and vessel in the exalted, let your echo resound in the felicitous cauldrons. Even Bo Cheng, a mere peasant, could distinguish the taste of fern—is that truly worthy of admiration?”

Master Juling replied: “I have heard that the subtle workings of the spirit are profound and obscure, the primordial chaos faint and indistinct. Fortune and misfortune intertwine in the interplay of hidden and manifest; rise and fall are entangled in the cycles of fullness and emptiness. The swift traveler cannot escape the shadow that pursues him; the joyful achiever cannot avoid the ruin that follows success. To correct the flow at its end is not as good as establishing order before signs appear; to mend what is already done does not compare to returning to the simplicity beyond the primordial.

Thus, the wise mantis willingly bends to preserve its extension; those who understand the cycles of opening and closing do not grieve or rejoice over adversity or prosperity. Moreover, the great potter shapes things, the great image flows into form—restlessness and stillness have different inclinations, soaring and sinking diverge in nature. Gold and jewels are prized for their weight; feathers are valued for their lightness. The narrow-minded cling to the mud and filth; the enlightened roam freely in the mysterious and pure. The stagnant pool receives the runoff and overflows; the vast sea swallows a hundred rivers yet does not fill. The gudgeon and shrimp leap joyfully in the mire; the red dragon soars mightily in the high heavens. Those who chew fragrant bait rush to their deaths in pursuit of desire; those who savor emptiness and blandness embrace the harmony of heaven and hasten toward life. Those who perceive the subtle workings of the spirit gaze upon the formless and are not deceived; those who are blind to good and ill blunder into the drawn crossbow and are not startled. Each follows his own inclination—how could they willingly change their course?

I have heard that the five jades cannot carve themselves from the mountains of Song; the soaring serpent cannot streak like lightning without mist; the Dragon Abyss cannot cleave rhinoceros and buffalo without being grasped; the great bell cannot resound without being struck. Golden mushrooms require the autumn wind to shine; the oriole awaits the smoke and fire of the sun’s vessel to sing. The fine steed does not recklessly gallop into danger; the gentleman does not compromise his name for a chance encounter. When the times are adverse, one sinks into obscurity; when the times are favorable, one towers in the celestial court. The scholar who flaunts himself is not esteemed; the woman who offers herself is not chaste. Why must one emulate the lofty standards of those who washed their ears, or imitate the vain glory of those who carried sacrificial meat?

In adversity, Yu wandered and fished, Jiang Taigong was driven away by a foolish woman, Fan Li endured humiliation in the privy, and Hong Yi concealed his marvels while herding. Yet in prosperity, Han Xin cast aside his fishing rod to become a lord, Wen Zhong left his corpse behind to don the blue robe, Fu Yue put down his trowel to discourse on the Dao, and Guan Zhong escaped his shackles to become chief minister. The gentleman conceals his vessel to await his time, accumulates virtue to act when the moment comes. If the time is not right, he does not appear; if the lord is not worthy, he does not serve. Obscurity or prominence depend on circumstance; action or withdrawal are not fixed. In stillness, he is the paragon of recluses; in motion, he is the foremost of the Eight Elemental Worthies. Some apply their thoughts to establishing words; some inscribe their merit on the vessels of state. Different paths lead to the same end; their purpose is one.”
